FeedItems.Title: Introducing Source Code Link for NuGet packages

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Clean orphan package registration on user delete" (#7299) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Remove orphan registrations on user delete. 

Addresses [Deleting a user does not remove their ownership from package registrations without packages](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7197)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[GitHub Usage] Add exclude list" (#7298) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Allow a configurable list of repositories that should be excluded from the GitHub indexing job's output.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch 'dev' into master" (#7294) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "[Deprecation] Packages show up in db2catalog slowly with big deprecation messages" (#7281) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Likely mitigated with
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7280

I deprecated 80 packages. Each had a deprecation message of 1,702,389 characters. This look 218 seconds for db2catalog to process.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Deprecation] Deprecation message has no reasonable length restriction" (#7280) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: I put a deprecation message that has 1,702,389 characters.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Locked-mode restore doesn't detect removed packages" (#8262) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.2.204 and 3.0.100-preview5-011568

### Automated repro
I've created a self-contained repro. Download 
[repro_extraStuffInLockFile.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3323115/repro_extraStuffInLockFile.zip) and run repro.bat.

###General details

1. Create a .csproj with a PackageReference
2. `dotnet restore --use-lock-file`
3. Remove the PackageReference
4. dotnet restore --use-lock-file --locked-mode

###Expected
The final restore should fail since packages.lock.json references packages that are no longer used.

###Actual
The restore completes without error

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NU5101 warning message repeats the recommendation" (#8261) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If I make a nuspec that specifies that some .dll files are to be put directly under `lib` directory in .nupkg file, `nuget pack` produces the following warning:

> WARNING: NU5101: The assembly 'lib\TestNugetPackage.dll' is placed directly under 'lib' folder. It is recommended that assemblies be placed inside a framework-specific folder. Move it into a framework-specific folder.

Is it really necessary to essentially say the same thing twice in last two sentences?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Use "$(SolutionDir)\packages\" Instead of Relative Path For Nuget Package References HintPaths" (#8233) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
My team members each have their own solution (.sln). Some developers manage a larger scale solution while others manage a smaller area of the entire scheme. Some developers include unit test projects in their solution while others don't. Currently, if someone references a package from NuGet, the proj file's hint paths get set to a relative path of the solution that was open when the package manager added the reference. This path may be invalid on another developers machine.
My current solution is to edit the proj file xml and change the relative path to the $(SolutionDir) variable. This works great. Could we have this happen by default or as an option?

_This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/558708/use-solutiondirpackages-instead-of-relative-path-f.html VSTS ticketId: 887957_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Jane Wu [MSFT] on 5/7/2019, 03:23 AM (37 days ago):

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion. We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further. We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Locked-mode restores fail with sha512 errors & install new packages when a project's RuntimeIdentifier is changed" (#8260) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

dotnet.exe --version: Both 3.0.100-preview5-011568 and 2.2.204

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

### Automated repro
I've created a self-contained automated repro. You can run it by downloading 
[repro_runtimeIdLockFile.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3322730/repro_runtimeIdLockFile.zip) and running repro.bat

### General behavior:
1. Create a csproj targeting runtime identifier A
2. `dotnet restore --use-locked-file`
3. Change the runtime identifier to B
4. `dotnet restore --locked-mode`

### Expected behavior
1. The second restore should fail with ` error NU1004: The packages lock file is inconsistent with the project dependencies so restore can't be run in locked mode. Please disable RestoreLockedMode MSBuild property or pass explicit --force-evaluate flag to run restore to update the lock file.`
2. The second restore should **note** install any packages (it's in locked mode)

### Actual behavior
1. The second restore fails with `error NU1403: The package runtime.osx-x64.Microsoft.NETCore.App.2.1.10 sha512 validation failed. The package is different than the last restore.`
2. OSX runtime packages are installed

...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Investigate migration from Newtonsoft.Json to System.Text.Json" (#8259) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Investigate current usage of Newtonsoft.Json to be able to better estimate effort of migrating to System.Text.Json

In particular, look for public APIs that accept or return Newtonsoft.Json types and therefore we can't remove without breaking APIs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Conditional package references and Locked Mode" (#8258) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Looking for guidance here…
Say you have a solution that contains .NET core projects and that reference NuGet packages using <packagereference> in the project files. Say that these <packagereferences> are made conditional using the existing MsBuild constructs such as `<choose><when>`, `<packagereference condition=””>` or optional includes of targets files that contain the package reference…

Say I have such a solution…
https://github.com/tfsaggregator/tfsaggregator

Now if I want to create a packages.lock.json, I could use `dotnet build --use-lock-file`, but that will create a single lock file, not conditional on the build platform+configuration. Now when I try to restore, it fails. Cause each configuration pulls in a different set of nuget packages. And of course only on set can match the lock file.

Is there a way to set the naming pattern of the lock file somehow? Say `packages.lock-configuration-platform.json`?! 

Is this included in the spec for nuget/dotnet? I can’t find this case in the docs so far.

Given that MsBuild supports conditional nuget references, I suppose that the package-lock feature should support it to in a fashion.

Now when I try to restore, it fails. Cause each configuration pulls in a different set of nuget packages. And of course only on set can match the lock file.

Is there a way to set the naming pattern of the lock file somehow? Say `packages.lock-configuration-platform.json`?! 

Is this included in the spec for nuget/dotnet? I can’t find this case in the docs so far.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Pack context menu should be hidden if the project is not packable" (#8202) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from Internal Bug https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/857426

## Details about Problem

Visual Studio context menu option "Pack" does not disable when the feature is disabled.

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): All

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create 2.2\3.0 ASP.NET Core project

2. Right click the project 

Expected: 

It should not show "Pack" as an option when 'IsPackable' property is set to false. 

Actual:

Pack options is available for all core projects irrespective of whether the project is packable or not?

The test time outs

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
